caption = Green in 2010 | fullname = Robert Paul Green<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/612828 |title=Updated squads for 2017/18 Premier League confirmed |publisher=Premier League |date=2 February 2018 |accessdate=11 February 2018}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1980|1|18|df=y}}<ref name=Hugman1011>{{cite book |editor-first=Barry J. |editor-last=Hugman |title=The PFA Footballers' Who's Who 2010–11 |year=2010 |publisher=Mainstream Publishing |location=Edinburgh |isbn=978-1-84596-601-0 |page=176}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Chertsey]], England | height = {{convert|1.88|m|order=flip}}<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.chelseafc.com/en/teams/first-team/rob-green?pageTab=biography|title=Rob Green|publisher=Chelsea F.C.|accessdate=21 February 2019}}</ref> | position = [[Goalkeeper (association football)|Goalkeeper]] | currentclub = [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] | clubnumber = 31 | youthyears1 = 1992–1999 |youthclubs1 = [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] | years1 = 1999–2006 |clubs1 = [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] |caps1 = 223 |goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2006–2012 |clubs2 = [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] |caps2 = 219 |goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2012–2016 |clubs3 = [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] |caps3 = 121 |goals3 = 0 | years4 = 2016–2017 |clubs4 = [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] |caps4 = 46 |goals4 = 0 | years5 = 2017–2018 |clubs5 = [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] |caps5 = 0 |goals5 = 0 | years6 = 2018– |clubs6 = [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] |caps6 = 0 |goals6 = 0 | nationalyears1 = 1997 |nationalteam1 = [[England national under-16 football team|England U16]] |nationalcaps1 = 1 |nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 1998 |nationalteam2 = [[England national under-18 football team|England U18]] |nationalcaps2 = 2 |nationalgoals2 = 0 | nationalyears3 = 2006 |nationalteam3 = [[England national football B team|England B]] |nationalcaps3 = 1 |nationalgoals3 = 0 | nationalyears4 = 2005– |nationalteam4 = [[England national football team|England]] |nationalcaps4 = 12 |nationalgoals4 = 0 | club-update = 14:28, 11 August 2018 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 14:28, 11 August 2018 (UTC) }} '''Robert Paul Green''' (born 18 January 1980) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] for {{English football updater|Chelsea}} club [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]]. He has also played for the [[England national football team|England national team]].
Green made his first-team debut for [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] in 1999 and totalled 241 appearances across all competitions for them, making the [[PFA Team of the Year]] when they won the [[Football League First Division|First Division]] in [[2003–04 Football League First Division|2003–04]]. In 2006, he transferred to [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]], making the same number of appearances in a six-year spell in which he was their Player of the Year in 2008 and won promotion via the Championship play-offs in [[2012 Football League Championship play-off Final|2012]]. He then moved on a free transfer to [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]], winning the play-offs again in [[2014 Football League Championship play-off Final|2014]]. In July 2016, Green joined [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] on a one-year contract.
Green represented England at [[England national under-16 football team|under-16]], [[England national under-18 football team|under-18]] and [[England national football B team|B level]]. He made his debut for the full England squad in 2005. Green was cut from England's [[2006 FIFA World Cup]] squad due to injury but featured in the [[2010 FIFA World Cup|2010 edition]], in which he started the competition as England's first choice goalkeeper but was dropped after an error cost England a win against the [[United States men's national soccer team|United States]]. He was also in their squad for [[UEFA Euro 2012]].
==Club career== ===Norwich City=== Born in [[Chertsey]], Surrey, Green came through the youth system at [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]].<ref name=Hugman1011/> He made his first-team debut in the [[Football League First Division|First Division]] on 11 April 1999, keeping a clean sheet in the 0–0 [[East Anglian derby|East Anglia derby]] draw against rivals [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] at [[Carrow Road]].<ref name=sb9899/> The first-choice goalkeeper since 1997-1998 remained [[Andy Marshall]] — on Marshall's departure in the summer of 2001 Green was able to establish himself as first choice goalkeeper for Norwich.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/n/norwich/1135257.stm|title=Green signs new Canaries deal|date=24 January 2001|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=11 May 2008}}</ref>
He was a star of the [[2001–02 Norwich City F.C. season|2001–02 season]] play-off campaign which culminated in a final loss to [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] on penalties.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} During the extra time period of this match Green saved an effort from [[Geoff Horsfield]] from point blank range.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}}
By 2003, Green was a key figure in the Norwich team.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} He played a key role in helping Norwich into the First Division championship in [[2003–04 Norwich City F.C. season|2003–04]] and promotion into the [[Premier League]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/n/norwich/3853249.stm|title=Green pens Norwich deal|date=30 June 2004|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=11 May 2008}}</ref> The Norwich number one was once again ever present, keeping another 18 clean sheets and conceding just 39 goals in 46 league appearances.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} Green put in many match winning performances during the season.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} These man of the match displays included home fixtures with [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] and [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]]; he pulled off a save from [[Gerry Taggart]] during the latter.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} Performances of this high standard led to his first England international call up for the friendly in March 2004 versus [[Sweden national football team|Sweden]].{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} He was also included in the [[PFA Team of the Year]] for the season.<ref name=pfa/>
Norwich were relegated into the [[EFL Championship|Championship]] the following season.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/4525103.stm|title=Fulham 6–0 Norwich|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=15 September 2014}}</ref> Green kept just 6 clean sheets and conceded 77 goals during the Premier League season despite many excellent individual performances.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} England coach [[Sven-Göran Eriksson]] continually picked Green for international squads on merit.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}}
After relegation Norwich struggled to adjust back to Championship football.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} It proved to be Green's worst season as Norwich's number one, keeping just seven clean sheets in 42 league appearances.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} Green missed the last few matches of [[2005–06 Norwich City F.C. season|2005–06]] after he sustained an injury in the warm-up prior to the away fixture against [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]].{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} In August 2006, Norwich accepted a bid of up to £2 million from West Ham United for Green.<ref name=whusigns>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/w/west_ham_utd/4791425.stm|title=Hammer Green eyes England recall|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=15 September 2014}}</ref>
===West Ham United=== [[File:Robert Green cropped.jpg|thumb|upright|Green playing for [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] in 2006]]
Green signed a four-year deal with [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]],<ref name=whusigns /> where he teamed up with former Norwich [[Forward (association football)|striker]], [[Dean Ashton]] who had been sold to West Ham in January 2006.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ex-canaries.co.uk/clubs/westham.htm |title=West Ham United |work=Flown From The Nest |publisher=Steve Whitlam |accessdate=7 December 2017}}</ref> Green made his debut for West Ham on 19 October 2006 in a 1–0 defeat against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] at [[White Hart Lane]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/6050700.stm|title=Tottenham 1–0 West Ham|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=15 September 2014}}</ref> Two of his best performances were when West Ham won 1–0 against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] at the [[Emirates Stadium]]<ref>[http://football.guardian.co.uk/Match_Report/0,,-73664,00.html "Green fingers revive Hammers' prospects"]. ''The Guardian''. London. 9 April 2007. Retrieved 23 June 2007.</ref> and against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] where he helped his team to a 1–0 win,<ref>[http://www.premierleague.com/competition/matchreport/report.html?id=2688764 "Manchester United v West Ham United, 0–1"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070614085811/http://www.premierleague.com/competition/matchreport/report.html?id=2688764 |date=14 June 2007 }}. Premier League. 13 May 2007. Retrieved 23 June 2007.</ref> which preserved West Ham's Premier League status.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/6627803.stm|title=Man Utd 0–1 West Ham|publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=28 August 2017}}</ref> Green kept nine clean sheets in 26 appearances during the league season.<ref name=whustats/>
In [[2007–08 West Ham United F.C. season|2007–08]], Green saved the first three penalties taken against him. The first, against [[Kevin Doyle]] of [[Reading F.C.|Reading]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sportinglife.com/football/premiership/westham/reports/story_get.cgi?STORY_NAME=soccer/07/09/01/SOCCER_Reading.html&TEAMHD=westham&DIV=prem&TEAM=WEST--HAM&RH=West--Ham&PREV_SEASON=2006 |title=Reading 0 West Ham 3 |work=Sporting Life |accessdate=3 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071202194821/http://www.sportinglife.com/football/premiership/westham/reports/story_get.cgi?STORY_NAME=soccer%2F07%2F09%2F01%2FSOCCER_Reading.html&TEAMHD=westham&DIV=prem&TEAM=WEST--HAM&RH=West--Ham&PREV_SEASON=2006 |archivedate=2 December 2007}}</ref> the second, [[Benjani Mwaruwari|Benjani]] of [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] in injury time,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sportinglife.com/football/premiership/westham/reports/story_get.cgi?STORY_NAME=soccer/07/10/27/SOCCER_Portsmouth.html&TEAMHD=westham&DIV=prem&TEAM=WEST--HAM&RH=West--Ham&PREV_SEASON=2006 |title=Portsmouth 0 West Ham 0 |work=Sporting Life |accessdate=3 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071202194954/http://www.sportinglife.com/football/premiership/westham/reports/story_get.cgi?STORY_NAME=soccer%2F07%2F10%2F27%2FSOCCER_Portsmouth.html&TEAMHD=westham&DIV=prem&TEAM=WEST--HAM&RH=West--Ham&PREV_SEASON=2006 |archivedate=2 December 2007}}</ref> and the third from Tottenham's [[Jermain Defoe]], again in injury time.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sportinglife.com/football/premiership/westham/reports/story_get.cgi?STORY_NAME=soccer/07/11/25/SOCCER_West_Ham.html&TEAMHD=westham&DIV=prem&TEAM=WEST--HAM&RH=West--Ham&PREV_SEASON=2006 |title=West Ham 1 Tottenham 1 |work=Sporting Life |accessdate=3 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110805063813/http://www.sportinglife.com/football/premiership/westham/reports/story_get.cgi?STORY_NAME=soccer%2F07%2F11%2F25%2FSOCCER_West_Ham.html&TEAMHD=westham&DIV=prem&TEAM=WEST--HAM&RH=West--Ham&PREV_SEASON=2006 |archivedate=5 August 2011}}</ref> The streak was ended by [[James McFadden]] of Birmingham City on 9 February 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportinglife.com/football/premiership/westham/reports/story_get.cgi?STORY_NAME=soccer/08/02/09/SOCCER_West_Ham.html&TEAMHD=westham&DIV=prem&TEAM=WEST--HAM&RH=West--Ham&PREV_SEASON=2006 |title=West Ham 1 Birmingham 1 |work=Sporting Life |accessdate=3 May 2010}}{{dead link|date=September 2016|bot=medic}}</ref> He played in every match and was named the West Ham Hammer of the Year with the team finishing in 10th place in the Premier League.<ref name="Green is Hammer of the Year">{{cite web |url=http://www.whufc.com/page/News/0,,12562~1310012,00.html |title=Green is Hammer of the Year |publisher=West Ham United F.C. |accessdate=28 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081124201923/http://www.whufc.com/page/News/0%2C%2C12562~1310012%2C00.html |archivedate=24 November 2008}}</ref>
[[File:Rob Green.JPG|thumb|upright|left|Green warming up for West Ham United in 2008]]
In [[2008–09 West Ham United F.C. season|2008–09]], Green saved yet another penalty, this time on 30 August 2008 against [[Jason Roberts (footballer)|Jason Roberts]] of [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]], West Ham then went on to win the match 4–1.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7578470.stm|title=West Ham 4–1 Blackburn|publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=28 August 2017}}</ref> Green played all 38 league matches for West Ham in that season, keeping ten clean sheets.<ref name=whustats>{{cite web |url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=2&ham=832&united=Robert_Green |title=Robert Green |work=Westhamstats.info |accessdate=7 December 2017}}</ref> And again played in all 38 league matches for West Ham in [[2009–10 West Ham United F.C. season|2009–10]], keeping eight clean sheets and saving yet another penalty, this time from [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]]'s [[Ashley Young]] in a 2–1 victory.<ref name=whustats/>
Green made 44 appearances in all competitions during 2010–11, keeping seven clean sheets.<ref name=whustats/> He saved a penalty in a 3–1 victory over [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] at [[Boleyn Ground|Upton Park]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/9221078.stm|title=West Ham 3–1 Wigan|publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=28 August 2017}}</ref> and then again against Stoke City in a 2–1 [[FA Cup]] defeat.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/9421244.stm|title=Stoke City 2–1 West Ham United|publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=28 August 2017}}</ref> On 19 March 2011, Green made a world-class save against [[Gareth Bale]]'s free kick in the 0–0 draw with Tottenham Hotspur at White Hart Lane.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/9425455.stm|title=Tottenham 0–0 West Ham|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> He was named [[West Ham United F.C.#Hammer of the Year|Hammer of the Year]] as runner-up to [[Scott Parker]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.whufc.com/articles/robert-green-west-ham_2228487_15045 |title=Robert Green Player Profile |publisher=West Ham United F.C. |date=18 January 1980 |accessdate=21 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110825233048/http://www.whufc.com/articles/robert-green-west-ham_2228487_15045 |archivedate=25 August 2011}}</ref>
Green was sent off for the first time in his club career.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2012/02/22/west-ham-united-robert-green_n_1292947.html | title=West Ham United's Robert Green Commits Another Howler After Red Card | work=The Huffington Post | accessdate=1 July 2013}}</ref> against [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] on 21 February 2012. West Ham, who had not named a [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] goalkeeper in their squad for the match, were forced to play the remainder of the second-half with midfielder [[Henri Lansbury]] in goal. They eventually won 4–1.<ref>{{cite news|title=Blackpool 1–4 West Ham|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/17023316|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=17 September 2016}}</ref> West Ham later won an appeal against the [[Red card (sports)|red card]] leaving Green available to play in their next match.<ref>{{cite news|title=West Ham United keeper Robert Green's red card overturned|url=http://www.guardian-series.co.uk/sport/westham/westhamnews/9550962.West_ham_keeper_s_red_card_overturned/|accessdate=23 February 2012|newspaper=East London & West Essex Guardian|date=23 February 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120224182511/http://www.guardian-series.co.uk/sport/westham/westhamnews/9550962.West_ham_keeper_s_red_card_overturned/|archivedate=24 February 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> He played 42 of West Ham's 46 match 2011–12 Championship season playing in the [[2012 Football League Championship play-off Final|play-off final]] at [[Wembley Stadium]] which West Ham United won, sealing their immediate return into the Premier League.<ref>{{cite web |title=Championship 2011–12 |url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=4&ham=2012&united=Championship_2011-12 |work=Westhamstats.info |accessdate=7 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Blackpool 1 West Ham 2 |url=http://www.sportinglife.com/football/cc_championship/westham/reports/story_get.cgi?STORY_NAME=soccer/12/05/19/SOCCER_Championship.html&TEAMHD=westham&DIV=nat1&TEAM=WEST--HAM&RH=West--Ham&PREV_SEASON=2010&BID=5149 |accessdate=13 June 2012 |work=Sporting Life |date=19 May 2012}}{{dead link|date=September 2016|bot=medic}}</ref> In June 2012, having failed to agree new terms with West Ham at the end of his contract, Green's departure from the club was announced.<ref name=exitwhu>{{cite news|last=Scott|first=George|title=ROBERT GREEN WANTED BY TOTTENHAM AND QPR AFTER QUITTING WEST HAM|url=http://www.dailystar.co.uk/football/view/254901/Robert-Green-wanted-by-Tottenham-and-QPR-after-quitting-West-Ham/Robert-Green-wanted-by-Tottenham-and-QPR-after-quitting-West-HamRobert-Green-wanted-by-Tottenham-and-QPR-after-quitting-West-HamRobert-Green-wanted-by-Tottenham-and-QPR-after-quitting-West-Ham|accessdate=13 June 2012|newspaper=Daily Star|location=London|date=4 June 2012}}</ref>
===Queens Park Rangers=== [[File:Chelsea 2 QPR 1 (15684368141).jpg|thumb|upright|Green playing for [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] in 2014]]
Green agreed terms with [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] (QPR) on 21 June 2012, and joined on a free transfer on 1 July, on a two-year contract.<ref>[http://en.espn.co.uk/football/sport/story/156630.html "QPR swoop for keeper Green"]. ESPN. 21 June 2012. Retrieved 17 September 2016.</ref> He made his debut on 18 August 2012 in a 5–0 home defeat by [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]].<ref name=qprdebut>{{cite news|title=QPR 0–5 Swansea|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/19221292|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=17 September 2016}}</ref> Green played only two more matches for QPR before manager [[Mark Hughes]] signed [[Brazil national football team|Brazilian international]] [[Júlio César (football goalkeeper, born 1979)|Júlio César]];<ref>{{cite news|title=Julio Cesar agrees QPR move from Inter Milan|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/19402928|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=17 September 2016}}</ref> although Green played the next match against [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]], this was only because Júlio César's work permit was not complete<ref>{{cite news|title=Rob Green victim of the Tony Fernandes QPR revolution|url=http://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/343355/Rob-Green-victim-of-the-Tony-Fernandes-QPR-revolution |newspaper=Daily Express |location=London |date=1 September 2012|accessdate=8 May 2013}}</ref> and the Brazilian started the following match, against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] on 15 September 2012.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/19528273 |title=QPR 0–0 Chelsea |date=15 September 2012 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
After the sacking of Hughes, new manager [[Harry Redknapp]] replaced Julio César with Green at half time during his first match in charge, against [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] on 27 November 2012. Green then went on to play the next five matches.<ref>{{cite news|title=Sunderland 0–0 QPR|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/20405369|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=17 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=QPR 1–1 Aston Villa|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/20474486|publisher=BBC Sport|date=1 December 2012|accessdate=17 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Wigan 2–2 QPR|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/20565003|publisher=BBC Sport|date=8 December 2012|accessdate=17 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=QPR 2–1 Fulham|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/20650099|publisher=BBC Sport|date=15 December 2012|accessdate=17 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Newcastle 1–0 QPR|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/20738242|publisher=BBC Sport|date=22 December 2012|accessdate=17 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=QPR 1–2 West Brom|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/20779094|publisher=BBC Sport|date=26 December 2012|accessdate=17 September 2016}}</ref> before being once again relegated to the bench<ref>{{cite news|title=QPR 0–3 Liverpool|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/20830243|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=17 September 2016}}</ref> for most of the next 4 months, only starting three matches between 26 December and 20 April,<ref name=sb1213/> two FA Cup matches in January then coming on when Júlio César was injured in the victory over Southampton<ref>{{cite news|title=Southampton 1–2 QPR|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/21556942|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=17 September 2016}}</ref> and playing the following match as the Brazilian recovered. Redknapp said following Green's third successive start in the loss to Arsenal<ref>{{cite news|title=QPR 0–1 Arsenal|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/22320618|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=17 September 2016}}</ref> that for the remainder of the season he "want[s] to play Rob Green" and that Green "will probably be [his] goalkeeper next season", as he expected Júlio César to be sold over the summer.<ref>{{cite news |title=QPR's Júlio César likely to be sold this summer, says Harry Redknapp |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/may/07/qpr-julio-cesar-harry-redknapp-rob-green |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=8 May 2013}}</ref> At the start of 2013–14, Green was named as first choice goalkeeper for the opening matches of the season.<ref name=sb1314/> Green was a member of the QPR team that won the [[2014 Football League Championship play-off Final|2014 Championship play-off Final]], 1–0 against Derby County at Wembley Stadium on 24 May 2014.<ref name="Derby County 0–1 Queens Park Rangers"/>
After a single season back in the Premier League, QPR were relegated after a 6–0 away defeat to Manchester City on 10 May 2015, Green's fourth relegation from the Premier League.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://talksport.com/football/man-city-6-0-qpr-aguero-hat-trick-sends-hapless-hoops-down-150510146244 | title=Man City 6–0 QPR: Aquero hat-trick sends hapless Hoops down | publisher=Talksport | accessdate=11 May 2015 | author=Moore, Joe}}</ref> Earlier in the season, on 26 December, he saved an early penalty in an eventual 2–1 loss to Arsenal, as his teammate [[Eduardo Vargas]] pointed out which way fellow Chilean [[Alexis Sánchez]] was likely to shoot.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Burnett|first1=Rob|title=Revealed: How QPR's Eduardo Vargas correctly predicted where Alexis Sanchez would put his penalty to help Rob Green save it|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/revealed-how-qprs-eduardo-vargas-4881192|accessdate=13 April 2016|newspaper=Daily Mirror|location=London|date=27 December 2014}}</ref>
After starting 2015–16 as QPR's first choice goalkeeper, Green was frozen out the starting line-up one match after the arrival of new manager [[Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink]] due to a clause in his contract triggering a contract extension if he played 30 Championship matches.<ref>{{cite news|title=QPR not playing Rob Green because of contract clause|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11711/10201779/qpr-not-playing-rob-green-because-of-contract-clause|accessdate=12 March 2016|publisher=Sky Sports|date=12 March 2016}}</ref> With QPR wanting to reduce the wage bill, Green left the club upon the expiry of his contract at the end of 2015–16, after a move to Premier League club [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] fell through in the January transfer window.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}}
===Leeds United=== On 6 July 2016, Green signed a one-year contract with Championship club [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36730294|title=Rob Green: Leeds United sign former England goalkeeper|date=6 July 2016|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> On 7 August 2016, Green made his Leeds debut against QPR in a 3–0 defeat, in which he failed to punch a ball from a corner leading to a [[Sol Bamba]] own goal.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.leedsunited.com/news/article/dw4fya4ld7kv11fnbvhw59zbt/title/qpr-claim-opening-victory |title=QPR claim opening victory |publisher=Leeds United F.C. |date=7 August 2016 |accessdate=7 August 2016}}</ref> Green was the match winner in the next match on 10 August 2016 in the League Cup against [[Fleetwood Town F.C.|Fleetwood Town]], when he saved a penalty from Fleetwood's [[Eggert Jónsson]] in a 5–4 penalty shoot-out victory after a 2–2 extra-time draw<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.leedsunited.com/news/article/18arte2t31o0w17cwlqra8yw4r/title/matchday-fleetwood-live! |title=Matchday: Fleetwood – Live! |publisher=Leeds United F.C. |date=10 August 2016 |accessdate=10 August 2016}}</ref> His first clean sheet came on 20 August 2016 in a 2–0 win against Sheffield Wednesday.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.leedsunited.com/news/article/z1zeauk05qph12f4qvpz29u2a/title/matchday-sheffield-wednesday-live! |title=United too strong for Wednesday |publisher=Leeds United F.C. |date=20 August 2016 |accessdate=20 August 2016}}</ref>
On 20 November 2016, Green committed a high-profile error when he dropped the ball under his crossbar onto the foot of [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] striker [[Dwight Gayle]] to tap the ball home in a 2–0 defeat.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37965461|title=Leeds United 0–2 Newcastle United|publisher=BBC Sport|first=Matt|last=Newsum|date=20 November 2016}}</ref> On 17 December 2016, Green kept his 8th League clean sheet for Leeds, this equalled the tally already for Leeds' clean sheet for the whole of the previous 2015/16 season with goalkeeper predecessor [[Marco Silvestri]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.yorkshireeveningpost.co.uk/sport/football/leeds-united/leeds-united-monk-s-man-given-the-green-light-for-a-reason-hay-1-8289574 |title=Leeds United: Monk's man given the green light for a reason – Hay |newspaper=Yorkshire Evening Post |location=Leeds |date=14 December 2016 |accessdate=14 December 2016}}</ref>
On 25 January 2017, Green kept his 6th consecutive clean sheet for home matches at [[Elland Road]] in a 2–0 win over [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailystar.co.uk/sport/football/582656/Leeds-Souleymane-Doukara-FA-Cup-Sutton|title= Leeds midfielder Souleymane Doukara hoping to win fans over after wonder goal |newspaper=Daily Express |location=London |date=25 January 2017|accessdate=25 January 2017}}</ref> After making his 600th league appearance, on 26 February 2017, Green saved a penalty from Sheffield Wednesday striker [[Jordan Rhodes]] in Leeds' 1–0 victory.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/watch/video/sports/football/10781143/blog-green-saves-penalty|title= Green saves Penalty!|publisher=Sky Sports|date=26 February 2017|accessdate=26 February 2017}}</ref> After impressing during his first season at the club, on 18 March 2017, Green signed a new one-year contract at the club.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.yorkshireeveningpost.co.uk/sport/football/leeds-united/leeds-united-rob-green-secures-elland-road-contract-extension-1-8445983|title= Leeds United: Rob Green secures Elland Road contract extension |newspaper=Yorkshire Evening Post |location=Leeds |date=18 March 2017|accessdate=18 March 2017}}</ref>
Green started the 2017/18 season under new Head Coach [[Thomas Christiansen]] as the club's second choice goalkeeper behind new signing [[Felix Wiedwald]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.leedsunited.com/news/team-news/22152/report-bolton-wanderers-2-3-leeds-united|title=REPORT: BOLTON WANDERERS 2–3 LEEDS UNITED|publisher=Leeds United F.C. |date=6 August 2017}}</ref> and made his only appearance of the season on 22 August 2017 in Leeds' 5–1 League Cup victory against [[Newport County A.F.C.|Newport County]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Leeds 5 Newport 1|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40932078|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=22 August 2017}}</ref> After the signing of [[Andy Lonergan]] on 27 August 2017,<ref>{{cite web|title=Whites Re-Sign Lonergan|url=https://www.leedsunited.com/news/team-news/22252/whites-re-sign-lonergan |website=Wolverhampton Official Website |accessdate=27 August 2017 |df=dmy }}</ref> Leeds reached a mutual termination the same day with Green to allow him to move to Premier League side [[Huddersfield Town]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Green Departs|url=https://www.leedsunited.com/news/team-news/22251/green-departs|publisher=Leeds United Official|accessdate=27 August 2017}}</ref>
===Huddersfield Town=== On 27 August 2017, Green signed for Premier League club [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] on a contract until the end of [[2017–18 Huddersfield Town A.F.C. season|2017–18]], after his contract with Leeds United was mutually terminated.<ref>{{cite web |first=Adam |last=Tomlinson |title=Signing: Robert Green joins Town |url=https://www.htafc.com/news/2017/august/signing-robert-green-joins-town/ |publisher=Huddersfield Town A.F.C. |date=27 August 2017 |accessdate=28 August 2017}}</ref> Green failed to make a single first-team appearance for Huddersfield and in May 2018, the club announced that his contract would not be renewed.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.yorkshireeveningpost.co.uk/sport/football/leeds-united/former-leeds-united-goalkeeper-rob-green-leaves-huddersfield-town-1-9170270|title=Former Leeds United goalkeeper Rob Green leaves Huddersfield Town|website=yorkshireeveningpost.co.uk|date=18 May 2018|author=PA SPORT|accessdate=13 June 2018}}</ref>
===Chelsea=== Green signed for Premier League club Chelsea on 26 July 2018 on a one-year contract to provide cover for [[Thibaut Courtois]] (and now [[Kepa Arrizabalaga]]) and [[Willy Caballero]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44957390 |title=Robert Green: Chelsea sign ex-England goalkeeper on a free transfer |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 July 2018|accessdate=26 July 2018}}</ref>
==International career== [[File:Teams head out for England & USA World Cup match 2010-06-12.jpg|thumb|upright|Green (wearing No. 12) enters the field with [[England national football team|England]] before a [[2010 FIFA World Cup]] match]]
Green earned his first call-up to the full [[England national football team|England]] squad in 2004 while at Norwich.<ref>[http://www.thefa.com/England/SeniorTeam/NewsAndFeatures/Postings/2004/03/SwedenvEngland_RobertGreen.htm "Happy to be here"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080328125002/http://www.thefa.com/England/SeniorTeam/NewsAndFeatures/Postings/2004/03/SwedenvEngland_RobertGreen.htm |date=28 March 2008 }}. The Football Association. 30 March 2004. Retrieved 23 June 2007.</ref> On 31 May 2005, he became the sixth Norwich player to wear the Three Lions shirt when he appeared as a half-time substitute for [[David James (footballer, born 1970)|David James]] in a 3–2 friendly win against [[Colombia national football team|Colombia]] at [[Giants Stadium]] in the United States.<ref>[http://www.thefa.com/England/SeniorTeam/NewsAndFeatures/Postings/2005/05/England_vColombia_Report.htm "Owen does it again"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080316024520/http://www.thefa.com/England/SeniorTeam/NewsAndFeatures/Postings/2005/05/England_vColombia_Report.htm |date=16 March 2008 }}. The Football Association. 1 June 2005. Retrieved 23 June 2007.</ref> Green remained in the England squad despite Norwich having been relegated into the Championship in 2005, and was selected for the England [[2006 FIFA World Cup]] squad.<ref>[http://www.thefa.com/WorldCup2006/NewsAndFeatures/Postings/2006/05/Squad_announcement.htm "World Cup Squad"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080610072505/http://www.thefa.com/WorldCup2006/NewsAndFeatures/Postings/2006/05/Squad_announcement.htm |date=10 June 2008 }}. The Football Association. 8 May 2006. Retrieved 23 June 2007.</ref> However, he ruptured his groin whilst taking a goal kick during the [[England national football B team|England B]] international against [[Belarus national football team|Belarus]] on 25 May.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/world_cup_2006/teams/england/5018328.stm|title=Keeper Green set to miss finals|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=15 September 2014}}</ref> He was replaced in the squad by [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]]'s [[Scott Carson]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/world_cup_2006/teams/england/5020060.stm|title=Carson promoted to England squad|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=15 September 2014}}</ref> The injury not only meant that Green missed the [[FIFA World Cup]] but also the start of 2006–07.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/n/norwich/5243322.stm|title=Green gears up for playing return|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=15 September 2014}}</ref>
After a prolonged absence from the international scene, Green was called up for the England "B" match in May 2007<ref>[http://www.thefa.com/England/SeniorTeam/NewsAndFeatures/Postings/Albania_Foster.htm "Injured Foster sent home"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080302093629/http://www.thefa.com/England/SeniorTeam/NewsAndFeatures/Postings/Albania_Foster.htm |date=2 March 2008 }}. The Football Association. 22 May 2007. Retrieved 23 June 2007.</ref> and then named in the senior England squad to face Brazil and Estonia in June 2007.<ref>[http://www.thefa.com/England/SeniorTeam/NewsAndFeatures/Postings/2007/05/EnglandBrazilsqaud.htm "McClaren names squad'] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080704145258/http://www.thefa.com/England/SeniorTeam/NewsAndFeatures/Postings/2007/05/EnglandBrazilsqaud.htm |date=4 July 2008 }}. BBC Sport. 26 May 2007. Retrieved 23 June 2007.</ref> He did not make [[Fabio Capello]]'s first England team in February 2008. Green showed a sense of humour about the international situation, sporting gloves with 'England's No.6' embroidered on them.<ref>{{cite news|last=Yates |first=David |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/2008/02/11/hammers-keeper-robert-green-pokes-fun-at-england-job-89520-20315915/ |title=Hammers keeper Robert Green pokes fun at England job |newspaper=Daily Mirror |location=London |accessdate=28 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081201154735/http://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/2008/02/11/hammers-keeper-robert-green-pokes-fun-at-england-job-89520-20315915/ |archivedate=1 December 2008}}</ref> He was recalled to the squad in place of the injured [[Chris Kirkland]] for England's friendly with [[France national football team|France]] on 26 March 2008.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/internationals/7309440.stm|title=Green called into England squad|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=15 September 2014}}</ref> On 6 June 2009 Green made his first England start in their 4–0 win in [[Almaty]] against [[Kazakhstan national football team|Kazakhstan]] in a [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification|2010 FIFA World Cup qualifier]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.whufc.com/page/News/0,,12562~1687748,00.html |title=Green keeps it clean |publisher=West Ham United F.C. |accessdate=15 September 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090615091733/http://www.whufc.com/page/News/0%2C%2C12562~1687748%2C00.html |archivedate=15 June 2009}}</ref> He played for England against Croatia on 9 September 2009 with England securing a place in South Africa with a 5–1 victory.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} On 10 October 2009, he became the first ever England goalkeeper to be sent off, during the penultimate match of qualification against [[Ukraine national football team|Ukraine]], for a professional foul on [[Artem Milevskiy]] early in the match. England went on to lose 1–0.<ref>{{cite news|last=McNulty |first=Phil |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/internationals/8293515.stm |title=Ukraine 1–0 England |publisher=BBC Sport |date=10 October 2009 |accessdate=28 April 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/news/newsid=1116076.html#england+fall+first+qualifying+defeat |title=England crash in Ukraine |publisher=FIFA |accessdate=28 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091013142935/http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/news/newsid%3D1116076.html#england+fall+first+qualifying+defeat |archivedate=13 October 2009}}</ref>
[[File:Robert Green Norway-England 2012.jpg|thumb|upright|Green playing for England in 2012]]
Green was named in England's squad for the 2010 FIFA World Cup.<ref>{{cite news |title=Official Players List |url=https://www.fifa.com/mm/document/tournament/competition/01/22/85/78/fwc_2010_squadlists.pdf |publisher=FIFA |date=4 June 2010 |accessdate=9 June 2010}}</ref> Manager Fabio Capello opted not to name his first choice goalkeeper until the day of England's opening match, against the [[United States men's national soccer team|United States]] on 12 June, at which point he selected Green to start.<ref>{{cite news |title=Capello defends goalkeeper delay |url=http://www.givemefootball.com/premier-league/capello-defends-goalkeeper-delay |publisher=Professional Footballers' Association |date=13 June 2010 |accessdate=13 June 2010}}</ref> After England went into a 1–0 lead, Green failed to save a long-range shot from USA midfielder [[Clint Dempsey]] in the 40th minute. The incident saw the ball bounce on and off Green's gloves and go over the goal line. This is known as his World Cup mistake.<ref>{{cite news| author=McNulty, Phil |title=England 1–1 USA |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/world_cup_2010/matches/match_05 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 June 2010 |accessdate=13 June 2010}}</ref> The match ended in a 1–1 draw. Following this error and an unconvincing final training session on 17 June, Green was dropped. He was replaced by David James who played in England's next match, a 0–0 draw against [[Algeria national football team|Algeria]] on 18 June.<ref>{{cite news|title=World Cup 2010: David James will play against Algeria |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/world_cup_2010/8747673.stm|publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 June 2010 |accessdate=19 June 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=England 0–0 Algeria|author=McNulty, Phil |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/world_cup_2010/matches/match_23|publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 June 2010 |accessdate=19 June 2010}}</ref> He did not appear again in the World Cup and was omitted from the first England squad named after the tournament for a friendly against [[Hungary national football team|Hungary]].{{citation needed|date=May 2018}}
Green was brought back into the squad for the [[UEFA Euro 2012 qualifying|UEFA Euro 2012 qualifier]] against Montenegro in October 2010.<ref>{{cite news|title=Goalkeeper Green recalled to squad for Montenegro qualifier|author=Sapa-dpa|url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/sport/soccer/article689425.ece/Goalkeeper-Green-recalled-to-squad-for-Montenegro-qualifier|publisher=Times Live|date=5 October 2010|accessdate=5 October 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101006071206/http://www.timeslive.co.za/sport/soccer/article689425.ece/Goalkeeper-Green-recalled-to-squad-for-Montenegro-qualifier|archivedate=6 October 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> On 16 May 2012, new England manager [[Roy Hodgson]] named Green as part of his 23-man squad for [[UEFA Euro 2012]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/18081125|title=England Euro 2012 squad: Ruddy, Carroll & Defoe in, Ferdinand out|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=17 September 2016}}</ref> On 26 May, he made his first appearance since the World Cup, and kept a clean sheet as England defeated [[Norway national football team|Norway]] 1–0 in a friendly.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/18184726|title=Norway 0–1 England|author=McNulty, Phil |publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=17 September 2016}}</ref>
==Personal life== In the summer of 2008, Green climbed [[Mount Kilimanjaro]] during a charity event for [[Amref Health Africa|AMREF]] (the African Medical and Research Foundation).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.justgiving.com/robertgreenkiliclimb |title=Robert Green's Kilimanjaro Climb |publisher=Justgiving.com |date=20 June 2008 |accessdate=28 April 2010}}</ref> He has stated that former Stoke City reserve-team goalkeeping coach Martin Phelan inspired him to become a goalkeeper after a talk at Green's primary school.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} He is a fan of [[Woking F.C.|Woking]] and cited the club's long-time custodian [[Laurence Batty]] as another goalkeeping inspiration.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wokingfc.co.uk/news/article/1635/ |title=Woking Football Club |publisher=Woking F.C. |date=15 September 2009 |accessdate=28 April 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/columnists/alansmith/2393038/Deep-thinker-enjoys-life-on-the-big-stage.html |title=Deep thinker enjoys life on the big stage |first=By Alan |last=Smith |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |accessdate=6 June 2016}}</ref>
Green stated in an interview with Leeds United that he is studying at the [[Open University]] for a BA Hons Business Management Degree in order to have something to focus on after he retires from football.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.leedsunited.com/news/team-news/21483/rob-green-the-perfect-degree-for-football-supporters |title=ROB GREEN: THE PERFECT DEGREE FOR FOOTBALL SUPPORTERS |publisher=Leeds United F.C. |date=7 January 2017 |accessdate=7 January 2017}}</ref>
